Unknown command: {{input}}
Type "help" to see available commands.
gitHubError: Internal error processing simulated GitHub command.
noRepoYet: It looks like your repository has not been initialized yet.
prIdMustBeNumber: The PR id must be a number.
unknownGit: Unknown git command: "{{sub}}". Use "git help" or "help" to see available commands.
blockedCommand: Command "{{cmd}}" is not available in this activity.
addDotLine1: This simulator does not use "git add .".
addDotLine2: ðŸ’¡ Tip: add files one at a time, for example:
helpInit: git init                    - Initialize a Git repo
helpBranchNew: git branch <n>              - Create a new branch
helpCheckout: git checkout <branch|hash>  - Switch to branch or commit
helpMerge: git merge <branch>          - Merge branch into current
helpConflicts: git conflicts               - List files with merge conflict markers
helpRemoteAdd: git remote add <n> <url>    - Add a remote
helpRemoteRemove: git remote remove <n>       - Remove a remote
helpPush: git push origin <branch>    - Push commits to remote
helpPull: git pull origin <branch>    - Pull commits from remote
helpPagesPublish: git pages publish           - Publish site to Pages
helpPagesRepublish: git pages republish         - Update published site
helpGhCreate: github create <n>               - Create simulated remote repo
helpGhStatus: github status                   - Show simulated remote status
helpGhPrCreate: github pr create <from> [to]    - Create simulated Pull Request
helpGhPrList: github pr list                  - List simulated Pull Requests
helpGhPrMerge: github pr merge <id>            - Mark simulated PR as MERGED
hintInit: git init creates the .git folder and starts tracking history for this project.
Use it only once when creating a new repository.
hintStatus: git status shows which files changed and whether they are staged (ready to commit) or not.
Useful to review before running git add or git commit.
hintAdd: git add stages files for the next commit.
Use it to choose which changes to include in a commit.
hintAddDot: git add stages files for the next commit.
In real life you could use git add . for everything, but here we practice file by file ðŸ˜‰.
hintCommit: git commit saves a snapshot of the staged files.
Choose clear messages so you remember what change was made in each commit.
hintLog: git log shows the commit history.
You can use git log branch-name to see another branch.
hintBranchList: Creating new branches lets you try things without breaking the main branch.
hintBranchCreate: git branch <n> creates a new branch pointing to the current commit.
Good practice: one branch per feature or task.
hintCheckout: git checkout switches the active branch.
Use it to move between versions of your project (e.g. main, feature/login, etc.).
hintCheckoutCommit: git checkout <hash> moves you to a specific commit (detached HEAD).
Useful to see how the project looked at that point in time.
To return to a branch: git checkout main
hintMerge: git merge integrates commits from another branch into the current branch.
If there are conflicts, resolve them in the files then run git add + git commit.
hintConflictsNone: Conflicts occur when two branches modify the same part of a file.
If you ran git merge and see no conflicts, the merge may have been automatic.
hintConflicts: git conflicts quickly locates files with merge conflict markers.
Combined with the editor, it guides you through resolving conflicts step by step.
hintPush: git push sends your commits to a remote (e.g. GitHub).
This simulator uses a fake GitHub so you can practice without touching real repos.
hintPull: git pull brings commits from the remote and merges them into your current branch.
Equivalent to: git fetch + git merge
hintClone: git clone copies a remote repository to your local machine.
The most common way to start working on an existing project.
hintRemoteAdd: git remote add configures a remote repository.
Then you can push/pull to that remote.
hintRemoteRemove: git remote remove deletes a remote configuration.
hintRemoteList: Each remote has a fetch and push URL.
hintPages: GitHub Pages lets you publish static websites from your repository.
Free and widely used for portfolios, documentation, and small projects.
hintPagesRepublish: Republish updates your site with the latest changes.
In real GitHub, this happens automatically on each push.
conflictNoFiles: No files with conflict markers (<<<<<<< ======= >>>>>>>) detected in /repo.
conflictStep1: 1. Open the file in the editor.
conflictStep2: 2. Choose which version to keep (or combine both) and delete the markers.
